DIV1.P: THE TRIAL OF William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, Soldiers in his Majesty's 29th Regiment of Foot, FOR THE MURDER OF Crispus Attucks, Samuel Gray, Samuel Mave∣rick, James Caldwell, and Patrick Carr, On MONDAY-EVENING, the 5th of MARCH, 1770, AT THE Superior Court of Judicature, Court of Assize, and general Goal Delivery, held at BOSTON. The 27th Day of November, 1770, by Adjournment. BEFORE The Hon. BENJAMIN LYNDE, JOHN CUSHING, PETER O∣LIVER, and EDMUND TROWBRIDGE, ESQUIRES, JUS∣TICES of said COURT.
Published by Permission of the COURT.
Taken in SHORT-HAND by JOHN HODGSON.
BOSTON: Printed by J. FLEEMING, and sold at his PRINTING-OFFICE, nearly opposite the White-horse Tavern in Newbury-street. M, DCC, LXX.

DIV1.HEAD: THE TRIAL OF William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, FOR THE MURDER OF Crispus Attucks, Samuel Gray, Samuel Maverick, James Caldwell, and Patrick Carr.
The Indictment was as follows.
DIV1.P: AT his Majesty's Superior Court of Judicature, Court of Assize and general Goal Delivery, begun and held at Boston, within, and for the County of Suffolk, on the second Tuesday of March, in the tenth year of the reign of GEORGE the THIRD, by the Grace of GOD, of Great-Britain, France and Ireland, King, defender of the Faith, &c.

The Jurors for the said Lord the King, upon their oath present, that Thomas Preston, Esq William Wemms labourer, James Hartegan labourer, William M'Cauley labourer, Hugh White labourer, Matthew Killroy labourer, William Warren la∣bourer, John Carroll labourer, and Hugh Montgomery labour∣er, all now resident in Boston, in the county of Suffolk, and Hammond Green boat builder, Thomas Greenwood labour∣er, Edward Manwaring, Esq and John Munroe, Gentleman, all of Boston aforesaid, not having the fear of God before their eyes, but being moved and seduced by the instigati∣on of the devil and their own wicked hearts, did, on the fifth day of this instant March, at Boston aforesaid, with∣in the county aforesaid, with force and arms, feloniously, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, assault one Crispus Attucks, then and there being in the peace of God,
and of the said Lord the King, and that he the said William Warren, with a certain hand gun of the value of twenty shillings, which he the said William Warren the and there held in both his hands, charged with gun powder and two leaden bullets, then and there, feloniously, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought, did shoot off, and discharge at and against the said Crispus Attucks, and that the said William Warren, with the leaden bullets as aforesaid, out of the said hand gun, then and there by force of the said gun powder, so shot off and discharged as aforesaid, did then and there, feloniously, wilfully, and of his malice a∣forethought strike, penetrate, and wound the said Crispus Attucks in and upon the right breast, a little below the right pap of him the said Crispus, and in and upon the left breast, a little below the left pap of him the said Crispus, thereby giving to him the said Crispus, with one of the bullets a∣foresaid, so shot off and discharged as aforesaid, in and up∣on the right breast, a little below the right pap of him the said Crispus, one mortal wound of the depth of six inches, and of the width of one inch; and also thereby giving to him the said Crispus, with the other bullet aforesaid, so shot off and discharged by the said William Warren as aforesaid, in and upon the left breast, a little below the left pap of him the said Crispus, one other mortal wound, of the depth of six inches, and of the width of one inch, of which said mortal wounds, the said Crispus Attucks then and there in∣stantly died; and that the aforesaid Thomas Preston, Willi∣am Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, John Carroll, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manwaring, and John Munroe, then and there, feloniously, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, were present, aiding, helping, abet∣ting, comforting, assisting, and maintaining the said Willi∣am Warren, to do and commit the felony and murder afore∣said.

And so the Jurors aforesaid, upon their said oath, do say, that the said Thomas Preston, William Wemms, James Harte∣gan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, Willi∣am Warren, John Carrol, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manwring, and John Munroe, then and there in manner and form aforesaid, feloniously, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, did kill and
murder the said Crispus Attucks, against the peace of the said Lord the King, his crown and dignity.
DIV1.BIBL: JON. SEWALL, Att. pro Dom. Rege. This is a true Bill. WM. TAYLOR, Foreman.
DIV1.P: At the same Court the said James Hartegan was indicted for the murder of Samuel Gray; and the said Thomas Pres∣ton, Esq William Wemms, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carroll, and Hugh Montgomery, for being present, aiding, helping and abet∣ting the said James Hartegan to do and commit the felony and murder aforesaid.

And at the same Court the said Matthew Killroy, was in∣dicted for the murder of one Samuel Maverick; and the said Thomas Preston, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, for being present aiding, helping, abet∣ting, and assisting the said Matthew Killroy, to do and com∣mit the felony and murder aforesaid.

And at the same Court the said John Carrol was indicted for the murder of one James Caldwell; and the said Thomas Preston, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, and Hugh Montgomery, for be∣ing present aiding, helping, abetting, and assisting the said John Carrol to do and commit the felony and murder a∣foresaid.

And at the same Court the said Hugh White was indicted for the murder of one Patrick Carr; and the said Thomas Preston, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery for being present aiding, helping, abetting, and assisting the said Hugh White to do and commit the felony and murder aforesaid.
On Saturday, the 27th November, 1770, the Court being met, the prisoners were brought into Court and set to the bar, when the Court proceeded thus.

DIV1.STAGE: The Jury were then called over and appeared.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: You the prisoners at the bar, these good men, which were last called and do now appear, are those who are to pass between our sovereign Lord the King and you, upon the trial of your several lives; if therefore you will challenge them, or any of them, you must challenge them as they are called to be sworn, before they are sworn, and you shall be heard.

The prisoners being asked whether they would agree in their challenges, consented that William Wemms should make challenges for them all.

SP.SPEAKER: Cryer.
SP.P: Gentlemen are ye all sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Clerk.
SP.P: Prisoners hold up your hands. Gentlemen of the Jury look upon the prisoners, and hearken to the charge. (The Clerk then read the several indictments against them as before set forth.) Upon each and every of these several indictments. the prisoners at the bar have been arraigned, and upon their arraignment have pleaded not guilty, and for trial have put themselves upon God and their country, which country you are; your charge therefore is, to enquire whether they or either of them be guilty of the felony and murder where∣of they stand indicted, or not guilty. If they or either of them are guilty, you are to say so; if they or either of them are not guilty, you are to say so and no more. Good men and true, stand together and hearken to your evidence.

DIV1.STAGE: Samuel Quincy, Esq addressing himself to the Court and Jury, opened the cause nearly in the following words:

OPENER.SALUTE: May it please your Honours, and you Gentlemen of the Jury.

DIV1.P: THE prisoners at the bar, are that party of soldiers be∣longing to his Majesty's 29th regiment, who in the evening of the 5th of March last, were induced from some cause or other to fire on the inhabitants of this town, in King street.

They are charged in five distinct indictments, with the wilful premeditated murder of five different persons mentioned in the respective bills; to each of these indict∣ments, they have severally pleaded, not guilty; and by that plea have thrown upon the crown the burthen of proving the fact alledged against them: It is my province therefore to give you evidence in support of this charge, and yours, gentlemen of the Jury, to determine whether they are guil∣ty, or not.

The cause is solemn and important; no less than whe∣ther eight of your fellow subjects shall live or die! A cause grounded on the most melancholy event that has yet taken place on the continent of America, and perhaps of the greatest expectation of any that has yet come before a tri∣bunal of civil justice, in this part of the British dominions.

I am aware how difficult, in cases of this sort, it ever is, and more especially so in these times, and in this trial, to pre∣serve the mind perfectly indifferent; but I remember, we are bound, not only by the natural obligations towards God and man, but also by an oath, to examine into the evi∣dence of fact without partiality or prejudice; I need not therefore caution you of your duty in this respect: It is upon that evidence and the law resulting from it, you gen∣tlemen are, in the language of your oath, to give a ver∣dict; and I will venture, before hand, to pronounce that verdict righteous, if it is founded in these principles as the rule of your judgment.

It has become my duty, it shall therefore be my en∣deavor, to acquit myself in the course of this trial with
decency and candour; reflecting, that however interest∣ing the question may be, the object of our enquiry is sim∣ply that of truth, and that this enquiry is to be conducted by the wisdom of the laws and constitution.

In support of this accusation against the prisoners at the bar, it is incumbent on the crown, to ascertain the follow∣ing things; viz. The indentity of the persons charged; the fact of killing; and the circumstances attending and aggravating that fact.

To this end, I shall immediately produce to you such e∣vidence, from the testimony of credible witnesses, as may be sufficient to sustain the several indictments, and when I have gone through the examination, make such remarks upon it, as may be most concise and pertinent to the pre∣sent issue.
The following witnesses were then sworn and examined in their order.
DIV1.STAGE: Jonathan Williams Austin, clerk to John Adams, Esq sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Do you know either of the prisoners at the bar?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Which of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: M'Cauley.—I knew the man before, but did not know his name; I was afterwards told it was M'Cauley. On the evening of the 5th of March last, I heard the bells ring, and immediately went into King-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: How many people do you imagine might be there when you got into King-street.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There might be twenty or thirty I believe.—I saw the Sentry at the Custom House door swinging his gun and bayo∣net; there were a parcel of men and boys round him. I de∣sired them to come away, and not molest the Sentry: Some of them came off and went to the middle of the street; I then left them and went up towards the Main-Guard. Im∣mediately a party came down, I walked by the side of them till I came to the Sentry box at the Custom House. M'Cau∣ley then got to the right of the Sentry-box; he was then loading his piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near was you to M'Cauley at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was about four feet off: M'Cauley said "Damn you, stand off," and pushed his bayonet at me: I did so:—Imme∣diately I heard the report of a gun.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near did M'Cauley stand to the corner?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He came round the Sentry-box, and stood close to it on the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When the party came down, were there many people there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot really say, I think about fifty or sixty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did they say to the people as they came down?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not hear them say any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you hear any orders given?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not, either to load or fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you hear the Seny cry out for help to the Main-Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; I was not there half a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Whereabouts did you stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I stood inside the gutter, close by the box.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Whereabout did the Sentry-box stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Three or four feet from the corner of the Custom-House.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: How many guns did you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Five or six, I cannot swear to any particular number.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you look round after you heard the guns fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see M'Cauley then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Was he loading again?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think he was; it so lies in my mind; (I cannot ab∣solutely swear it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know whether any soldiers stood on the right of M'Cauley?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took so particular notice of M'Cauley, that I mind∣ed no other object.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know any of the prisoners at the bar?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I particularly saw that tall man, (pointing to Warren, one of the prisoners.) Next day after the firing in K. street, I saw more of them whom I cannot particularly swear to now.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see the soldiers before the justices on exami∣nation?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you then observe you had seen any of them the night before in King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was well persuaded next day in my own mind, that I saw that tall one; but a few days after, I saw another man belonging to the same regiment, so very like him, that I doubt whither I am not mistaken with regard to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any other of the party you knew?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I am well satisfied I saw the Corporal there.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see White there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was the situation of the Corporal?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was the corner man at the left of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see either of the persons, you think you know, discharge their guns?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; the man I take to be the tall man, discharged his piece as it was upon a level.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see the Corporal discharge his gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did you stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was behind them in the circle.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What part of the circle did the tall man stand in?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He stood next but one to the Corporal. The tall man whoever he was, was the man I saw discharge his piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any thing thrown at the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, there were many things thrown, what they were I cannot say.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How did the Soldiers stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They stood with their pieces before them to defend themselves; and as soon as they had placed themselves, a party, about twelve in number, with sticks in their hands, who stood in the middle of the street, gave three cheers, and immediately surrounded the soldiers, and struck upon their guns with their sticks, and passed along the front of the soldiers, towards Royal exchange-lane, striking the soldi∣ers guns as they passed; numbers were continually coming down the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any person take hold of any of the guns or bayonets of any of the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not remember I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any particular words from this party of twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard no particular words, there was such a noise I could not distinguish any words.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did they load their guns before the people surround∣ed them, or after?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were loading at the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near did they go to the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Very near them, almost close to their guns.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the people who struck the guns, there at the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot say whether they had gone away or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you apprehend the soldiers in danger, from any thing you saw?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Where did you stand at the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I kept my place. At the time of the firing of the first gun, I heard a clattering noise on the right like one gun striking against another, and immediately the first gun was fired from the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: At the time of firing that gun was any assault made on the person that fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not see the person that fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You said, you saw several blows struck upon the guns, I should like you would make it more plain.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw the people near me on the left, strike the soldiers guns, daring them to fire, and called them cow∣ardly asls, for bringing arms against naked men; bid them lay aside their guns, and they were their men.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see any person fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw Gray fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where was that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He fell in the middle of the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the place where he fell nearly opposite to the tall man you talk of?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; the gun that killed him, must have been nearer to the center. When the soldiers on the left fired, there were fewer people on the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see a molatto among those persons who sur∣rounded the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did they seem to be sailors or town's men.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were dressed some of them in the habits of sai∣lors.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any bell ring?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What bell?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe all the bells in town were ringing, I heard the Old South first.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the clattering or blows on the guns to the right, im∣mediately before the first gun went off, appear very violent?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, very violent.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where was the second gun fired from?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took it to be the person next to him who fired the first, or very near him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Betwixt the first and second gun, did you see any as∣sault given to the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: When the firing came along to the left, were there many people in the street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There were very few people then in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What place did those few stand in?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Right over the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you looking at the person who fired the last gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw him aim at a lad that was running down the middle of the street, and kept the motion of his gun after him a considerable time, and then fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the lad fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He did not, I kept ay eye on him a considerable time.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: This soldier was towards the left you say, was he quite to the left?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not quite, but towards it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Was the lad among the party that struck at the sol∣diers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was passing the street, I cannot say where he came from.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: After the firing of the first gun did the people dis∣perse?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They drew away down Royal-exchange-lane, but others were coming continually down the street; but when the first person was killed, they seemed all to draw off.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the people that came down the street, endeavour to join the party that was striking the soldiers, or did they come because of the ringing of the bells?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe they came because the bells were ringing, for they came from all parts of the town, and did not ap∣pear to me to join in the assault.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many guns were fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many soldiers were of the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not count them, but I believe twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know either of the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I know Warren, and saw him with the party in King-street on the evening of the 5th of March last—

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know any of the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I know them all by sight, but that is the only person I can swear to.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: The night of the firing, did you see the Corporal there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not so as to know him; but Warren I can swear to.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see him discharge his piece?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No: I went away when the first gun fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did the person stand, who fired the first gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He stood towards the left of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Whereabout did you stand yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Opposite the soldiers, by Mr. Warden's shop the barber.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw none fall. I went off when the first gun was fired, and came back again and heard there were three men killed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you mean the first gun was fired from your left, or from the left of the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the left of the party; there were two stood to the left of Warren.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What appeared to be the conduct of the soldiers before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: When I got there, they were swinging there guns backward and forward, and several among the people, said, fire, damn you fire; but I think it was Capt. Preston that gave the word to fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many people were there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took them to be about fifty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What had they in their hands?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They had nothing in their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any ice or snow-balls thrown at the sol∣diers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw several snow balls and pieces of ice thrown, and heard a rattling against the barrels of their guns, whether it was sticks, or what, I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did the snow-balls seem to come from?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the people right before the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the snow-balls seem to be thrown in anger?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know; I saw the soldiers pushing at the peo∣ple before any snow balls were thrown.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Were the people pressing on?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were very near, within reach of their bayonets.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any oyster-shells thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the snow trodden down, or melted away by the Custom-House?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, the street was all covered like a cake.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the prisoners in King-street on the 5th March.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, before the affray happened.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which of them was it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was White. He was standing Sentry at the Custom-house: he spoke to me, and asked me how we all did at home. I immediately went home. Soon after I heard the bells ring, and went into King-street. When I came there, the soldiers were drawn up by the Main Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you there at the time of the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you spoke to the Sentry, was there any body with him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, he was walking backwards and forwards by himself.

DIV1.P: I am one of the Town watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you in King-street that evening the 5th March?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes. The bells began to ring, and the people cryed fire: I run with the rest, and went into King-street; I asked where the fire was; I was told there was no fire, but that the soldiers at Murray's barracks had got out, and had been fighting with the inhabitants, but that they had drove them back again. I went to the barracks, and found the affair was over there. I came back, and just as I got to the Town pump, I saw twenty or five and twenty boys going into King-street. I went into King-street myself, and saw several boys and young men about the Sentry box at the Custom house. I asked them what was the matter. They said the Sentry had knocked down a boy. They crowded in o∣ver the gutter; I told them to let the Sentry alone. He went up the steps of the Custom-house, and knocked at the door, but could not get in. I told him not to be afraid, they were only boys, and would not hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know the Sentry?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Is he among the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, that's he. (Pointing to White.)

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know any of the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, that man. (Pointing to Killroy.) The boys were swearing and speaking bad words, but they threw nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they pressing on him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were as far as the gutter, and he went up the steps and called out, but what he said I do not remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did he call loud?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, pretty loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: To whom did he call?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know; when he went up the steps he levelled his piece with his bayonet fixed. As I was talking with the Sentry, and telling him not to be afraid, the soldiers came down, and when they came, I drew back from the Sentry towards Royal-exchange lane, and there I stood. I did not see them load, but somebody said, are you loaded; and Samuel Gray, who was shot that night, came and struck me on the shoulder, and said, Langford, what's here to pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What said you to Gray then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I said I did not know what was to pay, but I believed something would come of it by and bye. He made no reply. Immediately a gun went off. I was within reach of their guns and bayonets; one of them thrust at me with his bay∣onet, and run it through my jacket and great coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where was you then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Within three or four feet of the gutter, on the outside.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who asked, are you loaded?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know whether it was the soldiers or inhabi∣tants.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear the word given to load?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard the question asked, whether they were loaded! but I heard no orders to load. Somebody then said, are you all ready: I then heard the word given to fire, twice distinctly.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many people were there before the soldiers at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About forty or fifty, but there were numbers in the lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they nigh the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were not in the inside of the gutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had any of the inhabitants sticks or clubs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know. I had one myself, because I was go∣ing to the watch, for I belong to the watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many soldiers were there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not count the number of them, about seven or eight I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who was it fired the first gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where about did he stand that fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He stood on my right, as I stood facing them: I stood about half way betwixt the box and Royal-exchange-lane. I looked this man (pointing to Killroy) in the face, and bid him not fire; but he immediately fired, and Samuel Gray fell at my feet. Killroy thrust his bayonet immediately through my coat and jacket;—I ran towards the watch-house, and stood there.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did Killroy stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He stood on the right of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was he the right hand man?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell I believe there were two or three on his right, but I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: You spoke to him you say before he fired, what did you say to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I said either damn you, or God damn you do not fire, and immediately he fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What in particular made you say do not fire?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Hearing the other guns go off.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many guns went off before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Two: but I saw nobody fall. Gray fell close to me. I was standing leaning on my stick.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Gray say any thing to Killroy before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He spoke to nobody but me.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he throw any snow balls?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, nor he had no weapon in his hand; he was as naked as I am now.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any thing thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw nothing at all thrown of any kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you talking with Gray at the time the gun went off?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not speak with him at that instant, but I had been talking with him several minutes before that.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you so near Gray, that if he had thrown any thing you must have seen it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, his hands were in his bosom, and, immediately after Killroy's firing, he fell.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any other gun at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: None, till I had got near to the watch-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near were the people standing to the soldiers, at the time that gun shot Gray?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were standing near the gutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any thing hit the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw nothing thrown. I heard the rattling of their guns, and took it to be one gun against another. this rattling was at the time Killroy fired, and at my right, I had a fair view of them; I saw no body strike a blow nor offer a blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you any doubt in your own mind, that it was that gun of Killroy's that killed Gray?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No manner of doubt; it must have been it, for there was no other gun discharged at that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know the Indian that was killed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body press on the soldiers with a large cord wood stick?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: After Gray fell, did he (Killroy) thrust at him with his bayonet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, it was at me he pushed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Gray say any thing to Killroy, or Killroy to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, not to my knowledge, and I stood close by him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you perceive Killroy take aim at Gray?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not: he was as liable to kill me as him.

DIV1.STAGE: Francis Archibald, Clerk to Mr. Price, sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the prisoners in King-street, that evening of the 5th March.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw Killroy go down with the party towards the Sentry.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took them to be six, besides the Corporal.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the rest there that you knew?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of them fire?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I was not near them; I went to Stone's door.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any snow balls or sticks thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you looking at the party and the people by them before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes. There was a noise amongst them; I was not near enough to hear what was said, but I saw nothing thrown.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where was you when the party came down?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Near the middle of the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you observe the party to divide themselves?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; the corporal walked in front of them, as he al∣ways does at a relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know who rung the bell at the Brick meeting house?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body get in at the windows of the Brick meeting house.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No. In Cornhill somebody said ring the bell, but who it was I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which bell rung first?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The Old Brick, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see what passed betwixt the soldiers and o∣thers at the barracks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About ten minutes after nine, I saw a soldier, and a mean looking fellow with him, with a culass in his hand; they came up to me: somebody said, put up your cutlass, it is not right to carry it at this time of night. He said, damn you ye Yankie bougers, what's your business: he came up to another that was with me, and struck him. We beat him back, when seven or eight soldiers came out of the barracks, with tongs and other weapons; one aimed a blow at a young fellow, John Hicks, who knocked the sol∣dier down. As he attempted to rise, I struck him down a∣gain, and broke his wrist, as I heard afterwards. I went to King-street, and when the guns were all fired, I saw se∣veral persons dead.

DIV1.P: N. B. The Court being unable to go through this trial in one day, the King's Attorney and the prisoners consented to the Court's adjourning over night dur∣ing the Trial, the Jury being kept together in the mean time, by proper officers, appointed and sworn by the Court for that purpose.
DIV1.STAGE: FIVE o'clock P. M. the Court adjourned to next morn∣ing, Wednesday. NINE o'clock.
Wednesday, NINE o'clock, the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Please look upon the prisoners, do you know any of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I remember this man (pointing to Killroy.)

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you in King street the fifth of March last?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, in the evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Please to inform the Court and Jury what you saw there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and as I got to the head of it, I saw the Sentry on the steps of the Custom-house, with his bayonet breast high, with a number of boys round him:
—I called to him, and said, I did not think any body was going to do him harm. I saw Capt. Preston and some sol∣diers come down.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which of the prisoners was the Sentry?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell, I was not so high him as to know his face.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many boys were there round him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think about twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How old were these boys?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About fourteen or fifteen years old, perhaps some of them older, I saw no men there except one, who came up Royal-exchange lane with me, thinking it was fire. He went back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did you take to be the reason that the Sentry charged his bayonet?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I could not tell what the reason was; there was no body troubling him. I was at the corner of Royal-exchange-lane, and a young man went up to the Sentry and spoke to him; what he said I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was yo there in the time of the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I went towards the Sentry-box, there I saw Capt. Preston. I said to him, Sir, I hope you are not going to fire, for every body is going to their own homes. He said I hope they are. I saw no more of him. He immediately went in amongst the soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What number of soldiers were there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think seven or eight, I did not count them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Capt. Preston lead or follow them down?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think he was upon the right of them. As they came down they had their guns charged breast high. I saw Christopher Monk, who was wounded that night, I turned to speak to him, and directly they fired, and he seemed to faulter. I said are you wounded, he said yes. I replied, I do not think it, for I then apprehended they fired only powder.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was it the first gun that you thought wounded Monk?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of these prisoners there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I saw Killroy, and that he was the man who struck me with his bayonet, when they came down, before they formed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did any body near you do any violence to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw none.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had you seen Monk that evening before?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, nor the day before.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near were you to the soldiers when they fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was about ten or fifteen feet from them, I stood in the street just above Royal-exchange-lane, about six or seven feet from the gutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Could you see the whole party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, they stood in a circle, or half moon.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you take notice of the distance betwixt the first and second gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was your back to them, when the first gun was fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, my face was to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did the firing begin?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Towards the corner of Royal-exchange-lane, I think it was the man quite on the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the man that struck you do it on purpose, or ac∣cidentally, do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think he did it on purpose, I apprehended it so; I was standing by the gutter, and he was before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Said he any thing to you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, nor I to him: he came to form, and I was closer than I wished I was, and he struck me.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How came you to speak to the Sentry, and tell him not to be afraid?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Because he was swinging his gun in that manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you come up Royal exchange-lane?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes. I saw Doctor Young there, and several others coming up to know where the fire was; Doctor Young said it was not fire, but that the soldiers had made a rumpus, but were gone to their barracks again. Then said I let e∣very man go to his own home.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any thing thrown at the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any body call them names?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any threatning speeches?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; except that the people cryed fire! fire!—the word fire, was in every body's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Just before the firing, when Killrey struck you, was there any thing thrown at the soldiers then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there a number of people betwixt you and the soldiers!

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not many.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see Palmes talking with Capt. Preston?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; I saw the molatto fellow there, and saw him fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see a party of people like sailors, coming down from Jackson's corner, with sticks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw none.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did you first see the molatto?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was just before me by the gutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any people coming from Quaker-lane with sticks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw several inhabitants coming through that lane, but I saw no sticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were there any coming up Royal-exchange lane?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, numbers, but I saw no sticks.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you first saw the molatto, did you hear him say any thing to the soldiers, or strike at them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had he a stick or club?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not take notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any huzzas or cheers as they are called?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard a clamour of the people, but I heard no cheers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear them call the soldiers any names?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any body say, kill them, damn them knock them over?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear the whistling about the streets at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any person strike with a club at the sol∣diers or any of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see them attempt to strike their guns?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear the rattling of the guns as though a stick had struck upon them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No. I heard the people around call fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you take that to be the cry of fire, or bidding the soldiers fire?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell now what I thought then?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many guns did you hear fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the word fire proceed from the people or from the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there a greater noise than usual, when the bells rang for fire?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not think there was so much. When I saw Dr. Young, he had a sword in his hand. When I came to King-street it was as quiet as I ever saw it in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the sword naked or not?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What sort of a sword was it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did Young say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He said it was the best way for every body to go home.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did any body huzza for King street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No. I said, every man home, and the word went round.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did not Dr. Young say the soldiers were beat to their barracks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; He said they had made a rumpus, and were gone to their barracks.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know if Dr. Young went into King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell, I left him in the lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the prisoners in King-street on the evening of the 5th of March last?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Carrel and Montgomery, and White who was the Sen∣try there.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I do not remember to have seen any of the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you there before the party came down?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: In what part of the street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I was standing along with the Sentry, on the Custom-house steps; I saw a number of boys round the Sentry.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What number?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Twenty or thirty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they all boys?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, none older than seventeen or eighteen years old.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did any thing pass between you and the Sentry?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, When I first went up to him, I said, what is the matter?—he said he did not know.—The boys were throw∣ing pieces of ice at him, and after I went to him, they threw no more; I stood with him five or six minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see the pieces of ice thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What sort of pieces, were they small or were they big enough to hurt a man?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, hard and large enough to hurt any man; as big as ones fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he complain any thing about it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He said very little to me, only that he was afraid, if the boys did not disperse, there would be something very soon, he did not mention what.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he tell them to disperse?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, he did not say a word to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the pieces of ice hit him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was nothing thrown after I went to him; if any thing was thrown, it was before.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How came you to go to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I went up to him because I knew him, and to see what was the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear him knock at the door?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he call for any assistance?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not hear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you there at the time of firing; please to recol∣lect the circumstances?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: When the soldiers came down, Carrol came up to me and clapt his bayonet to my breast, and White said do not hurt him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was that before the soldiers had formed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; immediately on their first coming down. I stood betwixt the corner of the Custom house and the post there, with my arm a top of the post.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear the first gun fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: From what quarter?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: From the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know the man that fired that gun.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was Montgomery, he was the very next person to me, close to me. When White told him not to hurt me, he took his hand and pushed me right behind him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did that first shot kill or wound any person?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What space of time was it betwixt the first and se∣cond gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Half a minute, or less.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any ice or snow thrown betwixt the first and second gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: There was a noise among the inhabitants, but I can∣not say what they said.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any thing thrown before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes; Montgomery was knocked down with a stick, and his gun flew out of his hand, and when he recovered him∣self he discharged his gun.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Do you know where he stood at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was the very corner man, on the right, close to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Who stood next him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know, but the man that stood the third from the right was Carrol, and I believe he was the next that fired

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you observe any, body strike Montgomery, or was a club thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The stroke came from a stick or club that was in some∣body's hand, and the blow struck his gun and his arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Was he knocked down, or did the gun only fly out of his hand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He fell I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What with the blow on his arm?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: His gun flew out of his hand, and as he stooped to take it up he fell himself; the blow struck his arm and might hit his body, for any thing I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see the person that struck him: was he a tall man?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was a stout man.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Was any number of people standing near the man that struck his gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, a whole crowd, fifty or sixty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When he took up his gun and fired, which way did he present?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Towards Stone's tavern, I imagine he presented to∣wards the Molatto.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How far distant was he from Montgomery when he fell?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About fifteen feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the rest of the persons fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No. When Montgomery fired, I stooped down, and when the smoke was gone, I saw three lying dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was the blow Montgomery received, upon the oath you have taken, violent?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, very violent.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: When you came to the Custom-house, and saw the boys throwing ice, where did they stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: In the middle of King-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they thrown as hard, as they could throw them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I belive they threw them as hard as they could.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there at that time a good deal of ice in K. street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, considerable broken ice.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Before the firing, after the party came down, did you see any snow balls, sticks, or ice, thrown at the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said to the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard nothing in particular said to them.—I heard the cry of fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any threats?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember your examination before the Justi∣ces?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you remember your saying they were throwing sticks and cakes of ice, in the mob way.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, not at the soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any cheers.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I heard two or three cheers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: What time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About two minutes before they fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you hear any thing said to this purpose, knock them over! kill them! kill them!

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did the people seem to be doing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They stood front of them, and were shouting; but I saw no violence done, but to that one man.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did the people do immediately on the firing of the first gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I could not see because of the smoak.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did Montgomery say any thing upon the firing of his gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not a word: nor any of the soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see a number of persons coming up Royal-ex∣change-lane, with sticks.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw a number going up Cornhill, and the Molat∣to fellow headed them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was this before the guard came down or after?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was before the guard came down.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many might there be of that party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Betwixt twenty and thirty: they appeared to be sai∣lors; some had sticks, some had none. The Molatto fel∣low, had a large cord-wood stick.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did they come down King-street afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not see them come down. I did not see the mo∣latto afterwards, till I saw him dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which way was the Molatto with his party going, when you saw them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Right towards the Town-pump.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which way did you go into King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I went up Royal exchange-lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: How long before the firing, was it, you saw them in Cornhill?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Six, seven, or eight minutes, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were the bells ringing then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What did the party with the Molatto do or say?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were huzzaing, whistling and carrying their sticks upright over their heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What number of sticks, do you suppose might be in the whole?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: seven or eight I suppose; some of them whistling, some huzzaing and making a noise.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know their design?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: I did not: when they went up Cornhill, I went up Royal-exchange lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any soldiers about that time in the street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw a number at Murray's barracks, and some officers driving them in.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know any of the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
I know Montgomery, I saw him in King-street with the party on the evening of the 5th of March last. I was with some gentlemen in company, I heard the bells ring after 9 o'clock; I went into King-street, and I saw the Sentry at the Custom-house door as usual, and no body with him: when I came to the Town-house, I was told the soldiers were abusing the inhabitants; I asked where, and was told at Murray's barracks. I went down there, and saw four or five soldiers, with their guns and bayonets; I told the offi∣cer who stood by, I was surprised they suffered the soldiers to be out at that time of night; an officer said, do you pre∣tend to teach us our duty Sir, I said no, only to remind you of it: You see, says he, the soldiers are in their barracks, why do not you go home. I saw Mr. Hickling, he was my neighbour, he said he was going home, we came up as far
ns the post office, where he left me; then I saw Mr. Spear, he said he was going to his brother David's; when I got to the Town pump, I heard a noise, and was told there was a rumpus at the Custom house; I said, I will go down and make peace, he said, you had better not go. I left Mr. Spear, and went down, and saw Capt. Preston at the head of seven or eight soldiers, with their guns, and bayonets fixed; I went to Capt. Preston, and saw Mr. Theodore Bliss talking with him, who said to Capt. Preston, "Why do you not fire," "God damn you fire." I stept betwixt them and asked Capt. Preston if the soldiers were loaded, he said yes, with powder and ball: I said, I hope Sir you are not going to fire upon the inhabitants, he said by no means: That in∣stant I saw a piece of ice strike Montgomery's gun, whether t sallied him back, or he stept one foot back. I do not know, but he recovered himself, and fired immediately. I thought he stept back and fired, he was the next man to Capt. Pres∣ton, the only soldier that was betwixt the Captain and the Custom house. When he fired, I heard the word fire, who gave it I do not know. Six or eight seconds after that, a∣nother soldier on the Captain's right fired, and then the rest one after the other, pretty quick; there was an interval of two or three seconds, between the last gun but one, and the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many guns were fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I do not know certain, seven or eight I believe, I did not count them. Before the last gun was fired, Montgome∣ry made a push at me with his bayonet, I had a stick in my hand, as I generally walk with one, I struck him, and hit his left arm, and knocked his gun down; before he reco∣vered I aimed another stroke at the nearest to me, and hit Capt. Preston, I then turned and saw Montgomery pushing at me again, and would have pushed me through, but I threw ny stick in his face, and the third time he ran after me to push at me again, but fell down, and I had an opportuni∣ty to run down Royal-exchange lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you take notice of the situation of the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw the form they were in, they were formed in a half circle.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Which way did Montgomery front?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He fronted the watch house.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you stand in a range with the watch house and corner of the Custom-house?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you certain that Montgomery was struck and sall back before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know whether it was with a piece of ice or club?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know whether it hit his body, or his gun, both?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It struck both, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any other violence offered, except th which struck Montgomery and the blows you emed and gav

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, no other.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Are you sure Montgomery did not fall, before h discharged his gun?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Upon the firing the first gun, did the people seem retire?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, they all began to run, and when the rest we firing they were a running.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the deceased fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not, but afterwards I saw Gray and Attu lying.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see all the rest of the soldiers discharge the pieces?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw the smoke, and it appeared to me at that tim they all fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: When the last gun was fired, where were the people

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were running promisouously about every whe

SP.SPEAKER: Court.
SP.P: Call James Bailey again.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Have you heard Mr. Palmes' testimony?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Are you satisfied, notwithstanding what Mr Pal says, that Montgomery was knocked down by a blow give him, immediately before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the prisoners at the Rope walks i the affray there, a few days before the 5th March?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw Carrol one of the prisoners, there with o∣ther soldiers in that affray.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know any of the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, the two furthest men, Hartegan and Carrol.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see them in King-street the 5th of March?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What time did you come into King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About a quarter after nine, after the party were come down.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were these two men of the party?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you there at the time of the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the party discharge their muskets?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, Montgomery.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know him before?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body strike him with a stick, or a stick thrown at him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Whereabouts did you stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About ten or twelve feet from Capt. Preston, I saw a little stick fly over their heads, but I did not perceive it struck any of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How large was it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took it to be a piece of a rattan.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any thing at all hit the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you looking at Montgomery when he discharged his piece?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body fall upon his firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I saw two fall, one fell at my elbow, another a∣bout three feet from me. I did not hear the sound of an∣other gun, before they both fell.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were they standing before Montgomery.

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, about twelve or fifteen feet from him, and about five feet apart, one was the Molatto, the other I did not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you think one gun killed both these men?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, for I heard no other gun when they fell.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you certain the other person was killed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any other gun before that man fell?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the Molatto say any thing before the gun went off?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard him say nothing. The Molatto was leaning over a long stick he had, resting his breast upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you in Dock square before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many people did you see there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw about twenty or thirty gathered up by the Town pump in the market, some with clubs; they went up Cornhill, most of them drest in sailors cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you then know where they were going?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They said let us go up to the Town-house. The bells were ringing at that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had they in general clubs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The biggest part of them had clubs,

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of them afterwards in King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, not that I knew

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see a tall man at the head of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I took notice of none in particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear a huzzaing before the firing, or see any thing thrown except that stick you mentioned?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had these persons when they were in Dock square, any clubs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About half of them had sticks; there were between twenty and thirty of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did they hold them up over their heads?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Some did, and some did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body with a sword, at the bottom of Royal exchange lane?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any soldiers there, about that time'

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What do you mean by clubs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were cord wood sticks broken up.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did any of them appear to be large?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were about as thick as one's wrist.
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and the first I saw was Montgomery, I saw him pushing his bayonet.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know Montgomery then?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: Yes: I drew back about five feet, and I saw his gun go off.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did Montgomery stand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: At the corner of the Royal exchange-lane, the right hand man of the party.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who did he push at?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How long after that before his gun went off?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had any thing happened betwixt that and the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw a stick knock up his gun.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know who it was knocked it up?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near did you stand to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About five feet off, within Royal exchange-lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did that stick knock up his gun before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes,

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did he bring it down before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He brought it down to the place where, it was before, and then he fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you looking at him all the time before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you certain, he did not fall before he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you sure, if he had fallen, you must have seen him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, from my situation I think I must have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What sort of a stick was it his gun was knocked up with?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It looked like a walking stick.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see him fall after he fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What occasioned his fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any body strike him, or at him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did his gun fall out of his hand?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think it did.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Are you sure that was before, or after his firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: After his firing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near were the people to him at the time of his firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Seven or eight feet off.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any other of the prisoners there that night?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you stay till all the guns were fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many were fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Six, I think, but I did not count them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: At the place where you stood, could you see the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, only two, they stood in a circular form,

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: After the first gun was fired, did not the people be∣gin to run down the lane?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any words spoke by the party of soldi∣ers or any of them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How long did you continue there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About five minutes, not longer: untill all the guns were fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you come from Dock-square up to King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any people there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I saw about twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What were they doing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were talking about going home.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Were the bells ringing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did they mention any thing why the bells were ring∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They said first it was fire, and then that the soldiers were out.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any cheers given in King-street?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I think I did before they fired.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Two I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who gave them?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The town's people.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How long before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About two minutes before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How were the people drest in Dock square?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Some in sailors cloths, some in surtouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had they sticks?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Some had, some had not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear them mention their going to the Town-house?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know either of the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, I know Montgomery, he used to live close by my house; I know none of the rest. I was at home the whole evening, the Old-south bell rung for nine as usual; about a quarter after, I heard Mr. Cooper's bell ring, I went out and I saw the Old south Engine haulled out. I ran down as far as the town-pump, there seemed to be a considerable body of people, and some with buckets. The people out of the chamber windows, said, do not go down there, you will be killed.—I saw ten or twelve soldiers with naked cutlasses by Boylston's alley:—I saw them with their cutlas∣ses and bayonets drawing up towards the people. I went back and stopped at the Main-Guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Were there a number of the town's people there at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, and many with buckets in their hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Were they contending with any body?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: No they were standing in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: What were the soldiers doing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They were brandishing their swords and sallying up to the people, but I did not tarry there one minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: What number of people were there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Thirty or forty.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Had the persons the soldiers came up to, any thing in their hands?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No they had nothing but buckets. I took it they were brandishing their swords at the people, but I saw them strike no body. I went to the Main Guard, I saw the Sen∣tries before the Guard house, walking as usual. I staid on purpose to see some body come back from Boylston's asley, to know if any were wounded. People were coming down from the South-end, crying where is the fire? Where is the fire I said there is no fire, but the soldiers fighting. At that time, in King street, I do not think you could see a man, child, or boy passing. I stood there at the Main Guard about four minutes.—The Old Brick bell began to ring, and the people seemed to come along fast, with buckets and bags.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did Mr. Cooper's bell ring before?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, a good while.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Could you see the Sentry at the Custom-House where you stood?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P:
No, I staid there about five minutes, and in a very short time I looked down King-street, and saw thirty or for∣ty people in King-street; Capt. Preston came down to the Main-Guard, as it were from behind the Brick meeting, and said turn out, damn your bloods, turn out: A party of sol∣diers turned out, Montgomery was amongst them; I was go∣ing to Montgomery, to ask what they were going to do?— They drew up in two files, I think there were eight men, Capt. Preston drew his sword, and marched down with them, and I went down as far as Mr. Waldo's shop with them, I thought they were going to relieve guard. After that, I went up by the Main guard again, having left the soldiers on their march down from Waldo's shop, and passed round the Town House, came down the north side of it, and went down King street, and got within two yards of the right of them; I saw Capt. Preston standing at the right of
the circle, I staid there about four minutes, when I heard the word given, fire!—There was none fired then.—Then I heard your bloods, fire!—Instantly one gun went off, I saw the flsh of every gun as they went off, one after a∣nother, like the clock striking.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did the firing begin?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It began at the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see Montgomery after he got down there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Where did you stand when the guns were fied?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I stood aboue two yards to the right, in Royal-exchange-lane and towards the back of the soldiers; I am positive the firing began at the right and went on to the left. I count∣ed the guns.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many were fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: Seven fired, and one flshed.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was there a longer distance betwixt the first and se∣cond gun, than betwixt the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No more than the rest, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any man fall?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not. there was a large opening at the centre, but on the right and left wings the croud was close and thick

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Could you see all the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I could not, there were many people between me and the soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see the person who held the gun that flashed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, but I did not know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Whereabouts was he standing?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: I believe, by the flash, he was the third or fourth man from the fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see any thing thrown at any of them before the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I stood all the time they were there, and saw no∣thing thrown at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see any body knocked down?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: You saw no ice nor snow balls?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the people round you seem to be pressing on so as to injure the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No; had I seen any thing thrown, I would have gone away.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any blows given by any body, before or after the firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know Mr. Palmes?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, I saw a man talking with the officer?

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know Mr. Bliss?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any huzzaing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, before the party marched down, there were two or three huzzas, but afterwards none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How many people do you imagine were there?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: sixty or seventy.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: From the time they went from the Main-Guard, till the firing, how long was it?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: It was not more than ten or twelve minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know either of the prisoners?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, White.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know either of the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes Wemms.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Do you know any other?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, Warren and Hartegan, I saw them there that night under arms. On Monday evening 5th of March, I was at work near Hancock's wharff, hearing a bell ring it caused me to leave the shop to make inquiry what the mat∣ter was; I heard the soldiers had rose on the inhabitants, and I got as far as Fanuiel-Hall. I saw several gentlemen, I asked them what the matter was, they answered me, that, two young men had been abused by the soldiers, but that they had returned to their barracks. The bells still ringing made me proceed up Royal-exchange lane with a number of other persons: I out run them and came to the head of the lane, there being no person there but a soldier who was the Sentry, the other Inhabitants coming up, they cryed out there is a soldier and huzza'd. The soldier immediate∣ly repaired to the Custom house door, he was at the west corner of the house before; there, with a large brass knocker, gave three loud and remarkable strokes.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What number of persons were there came up immedi∣ately after you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Five or six. Somebody came to the door and opened it, and spoke to the Sentry, and then shut the door again.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What was said to him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not hear. The soldier then turned about and loaded his gun, and knocked it twice very loud on the steps; then he went to the west corner of the house where he had been before, the people gathered round him; I went with him, and I cast my eye up King-street, and saw an officer and seven men, they came to the west corner of the Custom-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was any thing done to molest them then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, nothing at all. The officer then cryed shoulder.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Do you know who that officer was?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I have seen him in the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: How many soldiers were with him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: How did they stand then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: They stood in a circle. The officer then said, handle your arms, ease your arms, secure your arms, support your arms, ease your arms, prime and load.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Are you certain he said all that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I am as certain, as I am of my own existence.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where did Capt. Preston stand then?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: He stood a little behind the soldiers towards the Cus∣tom-house. There were about fifteen or twenty inhabitants in the street, when the party came down.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Were the soldiers formed before they loaded?

SP.SPEAKER: A
SP.P: They were not really formed: they were in a kind of a circle, after they had loaded they formed more into a circle than they were before.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you know Capt. Preston before that?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you there when the guns fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I went up to the officer, and said for God's sake do not fire on these people: he made me no answer at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Where was he then?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He was standing behind the soldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was you behind the soldiers?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, a little before them, at the edge of the gutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any person with him?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No, none at all. I pushed through betwixt two of the men, and spoke to him that way, he had on a red cont, and laced hat. I saw no more of him. I went to some of the inhabitants, and said, do not trouble these men, they are on duty. Some said we will neither trouble them, not be drove off by them.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear any orders given for firing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I heard, damn you fire: it seemed to me as it came from the Sentry-box where I left the Captain. I was then by Vernon the barber's shop; I had passed across the street. I saw a man going to throw a club, I begged of him not to do it, for I said if he did, the soldiers would certainly fire: he said, he would not, and did not. I then saw a white club thrown at some distance from me towards the soldier's; immediately I heard the word present, I stooped down, a little space of time ensued, I heard damn you fire: two guns were discharged then as I judged.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did that club hit any body?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I believe it hit one of the soldiers guns, I heard it strike.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Was that before the firing, or after?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Before the firing.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How near to the soldiers was the person that threw the club?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: About ten yards off. Three or four more guns were then discharged, which killed Attucks and Cray, I heard and saw them fall; then two more were discharged, one of them killed Mr Caldwell, who was about ten feet distance from me, the other struck about five inches over my back.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What space of time was there betwixt the second gun and the third?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took it to be about two or three seconds. Another gun was then fired, which wounded Mr. Patterson in the arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How long after the club was thrown, was it, before the first gun was fired?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not above one or two seconds.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What sort of a stick was it that was thrown?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I took it to be a white birch cord-wood stick, an inch thick.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: What fort of a man, for heighth, was he that threw it!

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He might be about five feet and an half.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: How do you know what number of guns were fired together?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: I judged by the report: I saw the flashes,

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you see any of the persons that were killed, that evening before they were killed?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Upon the oath you have taken, did that man throw the stick with considerable violence, or not?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: He threw it considerable hard, he threw it over hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Were any people standing betwixt the soldiers and the man that threw that stick?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, some, but not many.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did the people make a great deal of noise and huzzaing?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Yes, considerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Did you hear them say to the soldiers, bloody backs, come on you bloody backs?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: No. I heard no such thing, but when the two first guns were discharged, some one cryed murder, and by the voice I think it was Maverick. These guns killed nobody, unless Maverick was then shot.

SP.SPEAKER: Q
SP.P: Did you see any of the prisoners the 5th March?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: Not so as to know them again. That evening, at the cry of fire, I came out of my house, and saw the people running down town, and I followed them; when I got by the Town-house, I saw some going down King-street, I went down also: At the Guard house, I saw a number of the sol∣diers running; I asked where was the fire, no body answer∣ed me. I went down to the middle of King-street, and while I stood there, was pushed from behind me with a bayonet. I turned round and saw a party of soldiers coming down, I asked one the reason of his pushing at me? he dumn'd my blood, and bid me stand out of their way, I said I would not, I was doing no harm to any man, and would not stand aside for any one; they passed me some on one side, some on the other. They came to the Sentry-box, faced round and formed a circle. I spoke to some of the inhabitants to speak to Preston, to know what the matter was; some body spoke to him, but what was said, I do not know. I saw Preston fall in betwixt the fourth and fifth man, the word was given fire! immediately the right hand man fired; after that I pushed in towards them, and they run a bayonet at me and wounded me in my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
SP.P: Who was it struck you?

SP.SPEAKER: A.
SP.P: The second man, the first gun was th fired, the se∣cond was not; the guns went off pretty quick

SP.SPEAKER: Q.
